readingPart.reading:
adipocytedermismelanin
basal layerkeratinsebum
collagenlunulastratum corneum
cuticle

questionContent.questionText:
1. A fat cell is a/an [adipocyte].

2. The half-moon–shaped white area at the base of a nail is the [lunula].

3. A structural protein found in skin and connective tissue is [collagen].

4. A pigment found in the epidermis is [melanin].

5. The deepest region of the epidermis is the [basal layer].

6. The outermost layer of the epidermis, which consists of ﬂattened, keratinized cells, is the [stratum corneum].

7. An oily substance secreted by sebaceous glands is [sebum].

8. The middle layer of the skin is the [dermis].

9. A hard, protein material found in epidermis, hair, and nails is [keratin].

10. A band of epidermis at the base and sides of the nail plate is the [cuticle ].

instructions.instructions: Select from the listed terms to complete the sentences that follow.

questionContent.questionText:
1. the outermost layer of skin: epi[dermis]

2. profuse sweating: dia[phoresis]

3. excessive secretion from sebaceous glands: sebo[rrhea]

4. inﬂammation and swelling of soft tissue around a nail: par[onychia]

5. fungal infections of hands and feet: dermato[phytosis/mycosis]

6. burning sensation (pain) in skin: caus[algia]

instructions.instructions: Complete the following terms based on their meanings as given.

questionContent.questionText:
1. squamous epithelium [Flat, scale-like cells]

2. sebaceous gland [Oil-producing organ]

3. albinism [Pigment deficiency of the skin]

4. electrocautery [Knife used to burn through tissue]

5. subcutaneous tissue [Contains lipocytes]

6. collagen [Connective tissue protein]

7. dermis [Connective tissue layer of skin]

8. melanocyte [Contains a dark pigment]

9. erythema [Redness of skin]

10. dermabrasion [Surgical procedure to scrape away tissue]

instructions.instructions: Match the terms with the descriptive meanings in the dropdowns.

questionContent.questionText:
1. pertaining to under the skin: sub[cutaneous]

2. abnormal condition of lack of sweat: an[hidrosis]

3. a  bnormal condition of proliferation of horny, keratinized cells: kerat[osis] 

4. abnormal condition of dry, scaly skin: [ichthy]osis

5. loosening of the epidermis: epidermo[lysis]  

6. yellow tumor (nodule under the skin): [xanth]oma    

7. pertaining to under the nail: sub[ungual]

8. abnormal condition of excessive hair growth: hyper[trichosis]

9. abnormal condition of nail fungus: onycho[mycosis]

10. removal of wrinkles: [rhytid]ectomy

instructions.instructions: Build medical terms based on the deﬁnitions and word parts given.

questionContent.questionText:
1. melan/o [black]

2. adip/o [fat]

3. squam/o [scale-like]

4. xanth/o [yellow]

5. myc/o [fungus]

6. onych/o [nail]

7. pil/o [hair/hair follicle]

8. xer/o [dry]

9. trich/o [hair]

10. erythem/o [redness]

11. albin/o [white]

12. ichthy/o [scaly/dry]

13. hidr/o [sweat]

14. ungu/o [nail]

15. cauter/o [heat/burn]

16. rhytid/o [wrinkle]

17. py/o [pus]

18. hydr/o [water]

19. cutane/o [skin]

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings for the following combining forms.
Match each of the following lesions with their illustrations in Figure 16-26 .

questionContent.questionText:
1. baldness [alopecia]

2. bluish black mark (macule) caused by hemorrhages into the skin [ecchymosis]

3. itching [pruritus]

4. acute allergic reaction in which red, round wheals develop on the skin [urticaria]

5. blackhead [comedo]

6. small, pinpoint hemorrhages [petechiae]

instructions.instructions: Give the medical terms for the following.

readingPart.reading:
acne vulgarisgangrenescleroderma
basal cell carcinomaimpetigosquamous cell carcinoma
decubitus ulcermalignant melanomasystemic lupus erythematosus
eczemapsoriasistinea

questionContent.questionText:
1. malignant neoplasm originating in scale-like cells of the epidermis [squamous cell carcinoma]

2. buildup of sebum and keratin in pores of the skin leading to papular and pustular eruptions [acne vulgaris]

3. fungal skin infection [tinea]

4. chronic disease marked by hardening and shrinking of connective tissue in the skin [scleroderma]

5. bedsore [decubitus ulcer]

6. necrosis of skin tissue resulting from ischemia [gangrene]

7. chronic or acute inﬂammatory skin disease with erythematous, pustular, or papular lesions [eczema]

8. widespread inﬂammatory disease of the joints and collagen of the skin with “butterﬂy” rash on the face [systemic lupus erythematosus]

9. cancerous tumor composed of melanocytes [malignant melanoma]

10. chronic, recurrent dermatosis marked by silvery-gray scales covering red patches on the skin [psoriasis]

11. malignant neoplasm originating in the basal layer of the epidermis [basal cell carcinoma]

12. contagious, infectious pyoderma [impetigo]

instructions.instructions: Match the pathologic skin condition with its description from the numbered list that follows.

questionContent.questionText:
1. contagious parasitic infection with intense pruritus: [scabies/scleroderma]

2. measles: [rubeola/rubella]

3. chickenpox: [varicella/eczema]

4. thickened excess cicatrix (scar): [keloid/tinea]

5. white patches on mucous membrane of tongue or inner cheek: [leukoplakia/albinism]

6. characterized by a rash: [exanthematous/gangrene]

7. thickening of epidermis related to sunlight exposure: [actinic keratosis/callus]

8. small, pinpoint hemorrhages: [petechiae/psoriasis]

9. large blisters: [bullae/pustules]

10. hyperpigmented macule or papule of skin (mole): [nevus/verruca]

11. sac of ﬂuid and hair over sacral region: [pilonidal cyst/ecchymosis]

12. a cute allergic reaction in which hives develop: [urticaria/vitiligo]

instructions.instructions: Select the term that best fits the definition given.

readingPart.reading: damage to the epidermis and dermis with blisters, erythema, and hyperesthesia
damage to the epidermis with erythema and hyperesthesia; no blisters
destruction of both epidermis and dermis and damage to subcutaneous layer

alopeciaexanthemtinea pedis
comedonesneviurticaria
decubitus ulcerpruritusverrucae
ecchymosisseborrheic dermatitisvesicles

questionContent.questionText:
1. blackheads [comedones]

2. moles [nevi]

3. baldness [alopecia]

4. itching [pruritus]

5. hives [urticaria]

6. bedsore [decubitus ulcer]

7. warts [verrucae]

8. athlete’s foot [tinea pedis]

9. “black-and-blue” mark [ecchymosis]

10. dandruff [seborrheic dermatitis]

11. blisters [vesicles]

12. rash [exanthem]

instructions.instructions: Match the medical terms with the more common names or descriptions provided.

readingPart.reading: increased growth of epidermal horny-layer cells due to excess pressure or friction

instructions.instructions: Describe how the following conditions affect the skin.

questionContent.questionText:
1. Two skin tests for allergy are [scratch test/patch test] and [patch test/scratch test].

2. The [Schick] test is an intradermal test for diphtheria.

3. The [Mantoux/PPD] test and the [PPD/Mantoux] test are skin tests for tuberculosis.

4. Purulent means [pus-filled].

5. A surgical procedure to core out a disk of skin for microscopic analysis is a/an [punch biopsy].

6. The procedure in which thin layers of a malignant growth are removed and each is examined under the microscope is [Mohs surgery].

7. A type of skin cancer associated with AIDS and marked by dark blue-purple lesions over the skin is [Kaposi sarcoma].

8. Abnormal, premalignant moles are [dysplastic nevi].

9. Removal of skin tissue using a cut parallel to the surface of the surrounding skin is called a/an [shave biopsy].

10. Destruction of tissue using intensely cold temperatures is [cryosurgery].

11. Scraping away skin to remove acne scars and fine wrinkles on the skin is [dermabrasion].

12. Removal of subcutaneous fat tissue by aspiration is [liposuction].

13. Destruction of tissue using an electric spark is [electrodesiccation].

14. Use of a sharp, spoon-like instrument to scrape away tissue is [curettage].

instructions.instructions: Give short answers to complete the following sentences.

questionContent.questionText:
1. Since he was a teenager, Jim had had red, scaly patches on his elbows and the front of his knees. Dr. Horn diagnosed Jim’s dermatologic condition as [psoriasis/vitiligo/impetigo] and prescribed a special cream.

 2. Clarissa noticed a rash across the bridge of her nose and aching in her joints. She saw a rheumatologist, who did some blood work and diagnosed her condition as [systemic lupus erythematosus/rheumatoid arthritis/scleroderma].

3. Bea had large red plaques develop all over her trunk and neck after eating shrimp. The doctor prescribed hydrocortisone cream to relieve her itching [urticaria/seborrhea/acne].

4. The poison ivy Maggie touched caused very uncomfortable [pruritus/calluses/keratosis], and she was scratching her arms raw.

5. Kelly was fair-skinned with red hair. She had many benign nevi on her arms and legs, but Dr. Keefe was especially worried about one pigmented lesion with an irregular, raised border, which he biopsied and found to be malignant [melanoma/Kaposi sarcoma/pyoderma].

 6. After 5 days of high fever, 3-year-old Sadie developed a red rash all over her body. The pediatrician described it as a viral [exanthem/eczema/purpura]  and told her mother it was a case of [rubeola/impetigo/scabies].

7. Several months after her surgery, Mabel’s scar became raised and thickened and grew beyond the boundaries of the incision. It had [hypertrophied/atrophied/stratiﬁed],  and her physician described it as a [keloid/nevus/verruca].

8. Perry had a bad habit of biting his nails and picking at the [cuticle/follicle/subcutaneous tissue] surrounding his nails. Often, he developed inﬂammation and swelling of the soft tissue around the nail, a condition known as [paronychia/onychomycosis/onycholysis] .

9. Brenda noticed a small papillomatous wart on her hand. Her [dermatologist/oncologist/psychologist] explained that it was a [verruca/pustule/ﬁssure] and caused by a [virus/bacterium/toxin]. The doctor suggested removing it by [cryosurgery/Mohs surgery/dilation and curettage].

10. Sarah, a teenager, was self-conscious about the inﬂammatory lesions of papules and pustules on her face. She noticed blackheads or [open comedones/wheals/bullae]  and whiteheads (closed comedones). She was advised to begin taking antibiotics and applying topical medications to treat her [acne vulgaris/scleroderma/gangrene].

instructions.instructions: Select the terms that best complete the meaning of the sentences.
